sentences: Brian Yorkey is an American playwright and lyricist.
section: N/A

sentences: His works often explore dark and controversial subject matter such as mental illness, grief, the underbelly of suburbia, and ethics in both psychiatry and public education.
section: N/A
== Early life ==

sentences: Early life ==
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Yorkey was born in Omaha, Nebraska, where he was raised, before his family moved to Issaquah, Washington.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He graduated from Columbia University in 1993, where he served as the Artistic Director of the Varsity Show.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He is an alumnus of the BMI Lehman Engel Musical Theater Workshop.
section: == Early life ==
== Career ==

sentences: Career ==
section: == Career ==
== Career == | === Early work ===

sentences: Early work =
section: == Career == | === Early work ===
== Career == | === Early work ===

sentences: Prior to bringing Next to Normal to Broadway, Yorkey was affiliated with Village Theatre in Issaquah, where he began as a KidStage student and eventually progressed to a seven-year tenure as Associate Artistic Director.
section: == Career == | === Early work ===

sentences: Four musicals written by Yorkey—Funny Pages (1993), Making Tracks (2002), The Wedding Banquet (2003), and Play it by Heart (2005)—were staged there.
section: == Career == | === Early work ===

sentences: While at Village Theatre, Yorkey founded the KidStage Company class which teaches teens to write, direct, and perform their own musicals.
section: == Career == | === Early work ===

sentences: Yorkey's frequent collaborator, Tom Kitt, joined him in assisting with the score to the 2008 Company Original, In Your Eyes.
section: == Career == | === Early work ===

sentences: He worked with composer Tim Symons, on other Company Originals such as Last Exit and A Perfect Fall.
section: == Career == | === Early work ===

sentences: During Yorkey's tenure as Village Theatre's Associate Artistic Director, he developed a comprehensive new works program, Village Originals.
section: == Career == | === Early work ===

sentences: The Village Originals program develops approximately ten new musicals each season, in various stages from reading to full production.
section: == Career == | === Early work ===

sentences: Yorkey is credited with the development of over 50 new musicals, including the 2010 Broadway musical, Million Dollar Quartet, which was nominated for Best Musical, Best Book of a Musical, and won Best Performance by a Featured Actor (Levi Kreis) in a Musical at the 64th Tony Awards.
section: == Career == | === Early work ===
== Next to Normal and subsequent work ==

sentences: Next to Normal and subsequent work ==
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work ==

sentences: Next to Normal began as a ten-minute-long piece called Feeling Electric, which recent college graduates Yorkey and Kitt wrote as a final project for the BMI Musical Theatre Workshop at the end of the 1990s.
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work ==

sentences: Their inspiration was a segment about electroconvulsive therapy Yorkey saw on Dateline NBC.
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work ==

sentences: Next to Normal was nominated for a total of eleven Tony Awards, including the Tony Award for Best Book of a Musical.
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work ==

sentences: The show won the 2009 Tony Award for Best Original Score, and Tony Award for Best Orchestrations.
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work ==

sentences: In 2010 Yorkey and Kitt were awarded the Pulitzer Prize for Drama for Next to Normal, citing "a powerful rock musical that grapples with mental illness in a suburban family and expands the scope of subject matter for musicals.
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work ==

sentences: "In 2013, Yorkey's musical with Kitt, If/Then, starring Idina Menzel, LaChanze, and Anthony Rapp, had its pre-Broadway try-out at The National Theatre in Washington, D.C.
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work ==

sentences: The musical subsequently opened on Broadway on March 30, 2014.
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work ==

sentences: The musical garnered a Tony Award nomination and Outer Critics Circle nomination for Best Original Score for Kitt and Yorkey, as well as a nomination for Best Performance by a Leading Actress for Menzel.
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work ==

sentences: In 2014, Yorkey's collaborative work, with Sting and co-librettist John Logan, The Last Ship opened on Broadway.
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work ==

sentences: The musical is loosely based on Sting's album The Soul Cages (1990).
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work ==

sentences: It opened on September 29, 2014.
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work ==

sentences: Yorkey and Logan were nominated for an Outer Critics Circle Award for their book.
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work ==

sentences: He co-wrote the book and lyrics, with Melanie Burgess, to Jesus in My Bedroom, an original musical, with a score by Tim Symons.
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work ==

sentences: Jesus in My Bedroom received a reading at Village Theatre's 13th Annual Festival of New Musicals.
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work ==

sentences: He wrote the music, with Kitt, for a  musical version of Freaky Friday with librettist Bridget Carpenter.
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work ==

sentences: Freaky Friday is produced by Disney Theatrical Productions, and had its World Premiere at the Signature Theatre (Arlington, Virginia) in October 2016.
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work ==

sentences: The musical began performances at the La Jolla Playhouse, San Diego, on January 31, 2017 running to March 12.
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work ==

sentences: The cast features Emma Hunton and Heidi Blickenstaff.
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work ==
== Next to Normal and subsequent work == | === Film and television ===

sentences: Film and television
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work == | === Film and television ===
== Next to Normal and subsequent work == | === Film and television ===

sentences: Yorkey adapted Jay Asher's bestselling novel, 13 Reasons Why, for Netflix, Paramount Television, and Anonymous Content.
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work == | === Film and television ===

sentences: It was released on Netflix in March 2017.
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work == | === Film and television ===

sentences: He scripted Sluts for Lionsgate Films.
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work == | === Film and television ===

sentences: His first feature film pitch, Time After Time, sold in a bidding war to Universal Pictures.
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work == | === Film and television ===

sentences: It is now fast tracked at Lionsgate/Summit with Bradley Buecker directing.
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work == | === Film and television ===

sentences: Yorkey is adapting Next to Normal's film adaptation for Anonymous Content and an untitled fashion musical for Paramount Pictures, Walter Parkes and Laurie MacDonald.
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work == | === Film and television ===

sentences: Yorkey and Kitt are also developing Score!, a theatre camp musical for Robert Downey Jr. to star in for Warner Bros.
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work == | === Film and television ===

sentences: More recently, he signed deals with Netflix to start the Echoes limited series, and adapt Neal Shusterman's book Game Changer into a series.
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work == | === Film and television ===
== Next to Normal and subsequent work == | === Future theatrical projects ===

sentences: Future theatrical projects ===
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work == | === Future theatrical projects ===

sentences: Yorkey was working with Tom Kitt on a musical adaption of Magic Mike, with Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa writing the book.
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work == | === Future theatrical projects ===

sentences: According to various news sources, on May 2 and 3, 2019, the creative team of Kitt, Yorkey and Aguirre-Sacasa have left the project and a private workshop that had been scheduled for the week of May 3 has been cancelled.
section: == Next to Normal and subsequent work == | === Future theatrical projects ===
